title: 108_s900
content: The Act is titled the "Lower Yellowstone Reclamation Projects Conveyance Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act titled "Lower Yellowstone Reclamation Projects Conveyance Act" defines key terms such as Diversion Works, Intake Irrigation District, Intake Project, and Irrigation districts. The Lower Yellowstone Reclamation Projects Conveyance Act defines key terms related to irrigation districts, including the Intake Irrigation District, Lower Yellowstone Irrigation District No. 1, Lower Yellowstone Irrigation District No. 2, and the Savage Irrigation District. The Lower Yellowstone Reclamation Projects Conveyance Act defines terms related to irrigation districts in North Dakota, including the Lower Yellowstone Irrigation Project operated by Districts No. 1 and No. 2. The Act also mentions the Memorandum of Understanding signed in 1999 between the districts and the Montana Area Office for project management principles. The Lower Yellowstone Reclamation Projects Conveyance Act outlines the transfer of project titles within the Pick-Sloan Missouri Basin Program, including the Lower Yellowstone Irrigation Project. This program encompasses various benefits in the Missouri River Basin, with a focus on irrigation development. The Lower Yellowstone Reclamation Projects Conveyance Act includes the transfer of project titles like the Lower Yellowstone Irrigation Project, Intake Irrigation Project, and the Savage Unit under the Pick-Sloan Missouri Basin Program. The Savage Unit is operated by the Savage Irrigation District in Montana, authorized by the Flood Control Act of 1944. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. CONVEYANCE OF PROJECTS. The Secretary will convey works, facilities, and lands of the Projects to Irrigation Districts in two stages, with the first stage including all conveyances except Diversion Works and the second stage for Diversion Works. Lands, easements, and rights-of-way will be conveyed by quitclaim deed. The conveyance of lands, easements, and rights-of-way is subject to permits, licenses, leases, and rights-of-use of record by third parties. Mineral rights are reserved by the United States, excluding sand and gravel, and subject to existing oil, gas, and mineral rights. Water rights will be transferred to Irrigation Districts according to Montana state law. The Irrigation Districts will purchase Reclamation withdrawn lands for operation and maintenance benefits. The Savage Irrigation District must pay the present value of the remaining water supply repayment obligation to the Secretary for transfer. The remaining water supply repayment obligation of $60,480 will be treated as full payment under Contract Number I1r-1525, as amended and extended by Contract No. 9-07-60-WO770. Additionally, the Pick-Sloan Missouri Basin Program (Eastern Division) power customers will pay $94,727 as consideration for the conveyance under this subsection. The Sloan Missouri Basin Program (Eastern Division) payment collected by the Western Area Power Administration in fiscal year 2003 is considered full payment for construction aid-to-irrigation. The Reclamation withdrawal for the Lower Yellowstone Irrigation Project is revoked. The Secretarial Orders related to irrigation works on specific lands are revoked, including those for lots in sections 2, 4, 6, 12, 20, 26, and 30. The Secretarial Orders for specific lands in Montana and North Dakota are revoked, including various lots in different sections. SEC. 4. REPORT. If the conveyance under this Act has not occurred within 2 years after enactment for first stage conveyances and 5 years after enactment for second stage conveyances, the Secretary shall provide a report to the House and Senate Committees on the status of the transfer. SEC. 5. RECREATION MANAGEMENT. Lower Yellowstone Irrigation District No. 1 and No. 2 must convey a conservation easement to Montana for protecting and enhancing conservation values on Federal lands to be conveyed. This easement allows for recreation. The Secretary will support irrigation projects like Lower Yellowstone and Intake Projects under the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Program. Irrigation Districts will receive power at a preference rate for their pumping plants. Additionally, measures will be taken to protect Yellowstone River fisheries. The Secretary will provide fish protection devices for the Lower Yellowstone Irrigation Project to prevent fish from entering the Main Canal and allow bottom-dwelling species to migrate. Cooperation with Irrigation Districts is required for planning and construction, with a 2-year completion timeline. Monitoring will be conducted by the Bureau of Reclamation and the Fish and Wildlife Service. The Bureau of Reclamation will establish a monitoring plan to measure the effectiveness of fish protection devices for 2 years after construction. The Commissioner will modify devices as needed within 3 years. Costs for planning, engineering, and maintenance are nonreimbursable. Irrigation Districts will be responsible for operating and maintaining the devices after modifications are completed. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of this section. SEC. 8. Upon conveyance of the projects under this Act, Irrigation Districts will not be subject to Reclamation laws or entitled to Reclamation benefits, except as provided in section 6. SEC. 9. After conveyance, the United States will not be liable for damages unless caused by negligence prior to conveyance. SEC. 10. Compliance with laws. The Secretary must complete necessary analyses to comply with environmental laws before conveyances occur under section 3.
